abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column examines New York City guidelines that discourage schools from allowing children outside in frigid or icy weather; observes that regulations could be considered finicky by the standards of other cities, and that some say depriving children of recess can have academic consequences.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Education Department discourages schools from taking children outside if certain temperature, ice and other metrics are met, but polices in many other cold weather cities make the guidelines seem overcautious.

headline.main: A Casualty of a Frigid New York Winter: Outdoor School Recess
